comments:
This is the first of a two-semester sequence in electrical and systems engineering
senior design. Student work focuses on project/team definition, systems analysis,
identification alternative design strategies and determination (experimental or by
simulation) or specifications necessary for a detailed design. Students receive guidance
on preparing professional written and oral presentations. Each project team submits a
project proposal and two written project reports that include coherent technical
presentations, block diagrams and other illustrations appropriate to the project. Each
student delivers two formal PowerPoint presentations to an audience comprised of peers
instructors and project advisors. During the semester there are periodic individual-team
project reviews.
Students found this class “disappointing.” They were hoping for a chance to
showcase the knowledge they had gained after three years of education from Penn
Engineering, which was not satisfied by this course. Rather, the class focused on
presentation sills, such as the visual appeal of a presentation. They also said that there
was “too much emphasis on report-writing and presentations and very little support for
the actual project.”
Students were not satisfied with Professor Laker as an instructor. They feel that
“little attention [was] paid to the engineering behind the projects.” Professor Laker
focused on the details of presentation, when students had hoped for more feedback on
their engineering project. They felt that their grades depended much more upon the
quality of their visual presentation than the quality of their project. Students opined that
the Professor Laker’s priorities were not in order.
The work required for this class was tedious, and often did not feel valuable. As
the senior design project class, this course is required for senior Electrical and Systems
Engineering majors.
Fewer than 8 student comments were submitted for this course.

This is the first of a two-semester sequence in electrical and systems engineering
senior design. Student work focuses on project/team definition, systems analysis,
identification alternative design strategies and determination (experimental or by
simulation) or specifications necessary for a detailed design.
Students generally found that this class spent too much time focusing on
presentation formatting and not enough on the actual engineering behind the projects. As
one of the courses that students wait their entire college career for, this course did not live
up to many students’ expectations.
Professor Scott is generally revered as a good professor; however, this class left
his students wishing for more advising and help behind the scenes of the project. His
assistance with formatting and careful eye for detail in presentations did not lend much
assistance to the students when actually working on their projects.
The work required for this class is time consuming and oftentimes tedious (in the
format of a lab notebook and other busy work), but outside of the class format, students
enjoyed their senior design project.
